issue.title: IDE with debugging for docker using ignition

content.raw:
I set up an own dockerfile to build a new image based on the subt docker image. In this docker file I included the installation of eclipse-cdt, which was a bit tricky. Using this new image I’m able to use eclipse for the development and use the debugging in eclipse. 

Today I‘m a little bit busy. If you want it, I can upload the dockerfile tomorrow evening.
content.html:
I set up an own dockerfile to build a new image based on the subt docker image. In this docker file I included the installation of eclipse-cdt, which was a bit tricky. Using this new image I’m able to use eclipse for the development and use the debugging in eclipse.

Today I‘m a little bit busy. If you want it, I can upload the dockerfile tomorrow evening.

content.html: Hi @Sophisticated Engineering , thanks for the answer. If there is no inconvenience for you, would you mind uploading the docker file. I’ll use it as an advice for rebuilding a new one. I really appreciate your help.

issue.title: IDE with debugging for docker using ignition

content.raw:
Here is the dockerfile I created:

```
# Subterranean Challenge - Solution Container
FROM subt_shell

# install Java
RUN sudo apt-get update \
 && sudo apt install -y default-jre \
    libcanberra-gtk-module  \
 && sudo apt-get clean

# install eclipse
RUN cd ~ \
  && mkdir eclipse \
  && cd eclipse \
  && URL=https://www.eclipse.org/downloads/download.php \
  && ECLIPSE=/technology/epp/downloads/release/2019-06/R/eclipse-cpp-2019-06-R-linux-gtk-x86_64.tar.gz \
  && MIRROR=1 \
  && wget -O eclipse-cpp-2019-06-R-linux-gtk-x86_64.tar.gz "${URL}?file=${ECLIPSE}&mirror_id=${MIRROR}" \
  && tar zxf eclipse-cpp-2019-06-R-linux-gtk-x86_64.tar.gz
```

After building and starting the docker container you can start eclipse in the docker container by using:

`cd ~/eclipse/eclipse/`  
`./eclipse`

If you need more details, just ask.
content.html:
Here is the dockerfile I created:

# Subterranean Challenge - Solution Container
FROM subt_shell

# install Java
RUN sudo apt-get update \
 && sudo apt install -y default-jre \
    libcanberra-gtk-module  \
 && sudo apt-get clean

# install eclipse
RUN cd ~ \
  && mkdir eclipse \
  && cd eclipse \
  && URL=https://www.eclipse.org/downloads/download.php \
  && ECLIPSE=/technology/epp/downloads/release/2019-06/R/eclipse-cpp-2019-06-R-linux-gtk-x86_64.tar.gz \
  && MIRROR=1 \
  && wget -O eclipse-cpp-2019-06-R-linux-gtk-x86_64.tar.gz "${URL}?file=${ECLIPSE}&mirror_id=${MIRROR}" \
  && tar zxf eclipse-cpp-2019-06-R-linux-gtk-x86_64.tar.gz

After building and starting the docker container you can start eclipse in the docker container by using:

cd ~/eclipse/eclipse/
./eclipse

If you need more details, just ask.

content.raw:
Hi @{5c0d82b3128c7106f57691a7} , I’m now creating the docker file you recommended. I have some questions on this. How can I build this docker file with the challenge’s docker file? I mean, I only use the ./run.bash command to run the challenge’s docker file, so how can I “connect” it? Can I use C\+\+ / Python in Eclipse instead of Java?

Thank you.
